register.description: The Global Enable Register has the master interrupt mask

bitfield.description: Always read as 0h. Writes have no affect.

This field is the global mask for all interrupts. It is reset by the warm reset. The purpose is to leave all of the raw status and per-interrupt enable bits alone so that, after a warm reset, software may observe the state of the ESM before the warm reset and try to debug what may have caused the reset.

register.description: The Global Soft Reset Register controls the global clear for raw status and enables

bitfield.description: Always read as 0h. Writes have no affect.
Global Soft Reset field. Writing to this field can cause all of the raw status and all enables to be cleared. This can be used to reset the ESM state after debugging because of a warm reset.

register.description: Shows which is the highest priority outstanding low priority interrupt

bitfield.description: Indicates what the highest priority low priority interrupt caused by a pulse number is. The lowest event has the highest priority. I.e. if Global Events 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4 are pending, and Global Event 0, and 1 are configured for high priority while Global Events 2, 3, and 4 are configured for low priority, then the value of this field will be 0x2. A value of all ones (0xFFFF) indicates that there are no low priority interrupts pending.

Indicates what the highest priority low priority interrupt caused by a level number is. The lowest event has the highest priority. I.e. if Global Events 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4 are pending, and Global Event 0, and 1 are configured for High Priority while Global Events 2, 3, and 4 are configured for low priority, then the value of this field will be 0x2. A value of all ones (0xFFFF) indicates that there are no low priority interrupts pending.

register.description: Shows which is the highest priority outstanding high priority interrupt

bitfield.description: Indicates what the highest priority high priority interrupt caused by a pulse number is. The lowest event has the highest priority. I.e. if Global Events 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4 are pending, and Global Event 0, and 1 are configured for high priority while Global Events 2, 3, and 4 are configured for low priority, then the value of this field will be 0x0. A value of all ones (0xFFFF) indicates that there are no high priority interrupts pending.

Indicates what the highest priority low priority interrupt caused by a level number is. The lowest event has the highest priority. I.e. if Global Events 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4 are pending, and Global Event 0, and 1 are configured for high priority while Global Events 2, 3, and 4 are configured for low priority, then the value of this field will be 0x0. A value of all ones (0xFFFF) indicates that there are no high priority interrupts pending.

register.description: Shows which groups have outstanding low priority interrupts

bitfield.description: Indicates which Event Groups have one or more low priority interrupts pending. This register is bit oriented where bit 0 is for Event Group 0, bit 1 is for Event Group 1, etc… (bit N is for Event Group N).

register.description: Shows which groups have outstanding high priority interrupts

bitfield.description: Indicates which Event Groups have one or more high priority interrupts pending. This register is bit oriented where bit 0 is for Event Group 0, bit 1 is for Event Group 1, etc… (bit N is for Event Group N).

register.description: End of Interrupt Register The EOI register is used to re-trigger the pulse interrupt signal to ensure that any nested interrupt events are serviced. The software interrupt handler must write to the EOI register at the end of the current interrupt processing routine, so that new events can re-trigger the pulse interrupt signal again. For level interrupt signals the EOI register is not functional and must not be used.

bitfield.description: Always read as 0h. Writes have no affect.

This is the interrupt being serviced. Writing the corresponding vector to this field will cause a re-evaluation of interrupts. If, when the vector is written, there are still pending interrupts, a new pulse will be generated. Reads always return 0.

register.description: This register controls the SAFETY_ERRORn pin output

bitfield.description: Always read as 0h. Writes have no affect.

Pin control key. This field controls behavior of the error pin. Note, during reset the field is 0h, but the error pin is asserted (active low). Immediately after reset, the error pin de-asserts. This field is only reset by a Power-On-Reset (not warm reset). A global soft reset will set this field to 0. A global soft reset will also CLEAR all pending faults.

register.description: This register reflects the status of the error_pin_n output

bitfield.description: Always read as 0h. Writes have no affect.

This field indicates the status of the error pin as looped back from the I/O. This field reflects the state of the ERR_I pin. Since the ERR_O pin is only affected by Power-On-Reset, then the value of this field may be 1h after the release of Warm Reset.
